title: (Super)latus
body: This works features two identical protagonists who are mutually critiquing each other with superlative adjectives, positives and negatives. Both counterparts become increasingly pixelated, censoring one another and disappearing over time. This work puts at stake the notion of critical subjectivity and the self-cancelling quality of such criticism. The vile for some may well be valuable to others. Even though it's often sterile, such criticism may sometimes create fertile antagonistic appreciations and clashes that result into third definitions.

title: Inter[...]Views
body: The work INTER[…]VIEWS is a series of videos found on the internet drastically re-edited. What remains from the original video is an abstract speech emptied out of its former subject matter outlining in this way the phatic expressions of the speaker. Consequentially the media is extremely censored. In these videos the spokesperson is caught in the moments where he/she is rhetorically thinking about what will be said and how. In turn, subtle signs of personal gesture and social conventions more forcefully emerge and render substantial the gap between language and idea.

title: Dirt

slides.legend: Installation view of the work Dirt, New Cross, London, 2012

medium: Carbon & oil on glass, spontaneous writing from the audience

title: Full Stops

slides.body: <iframe src="//player.vimeo.com/video/83450978?title=0&byline=0&portrait=0&color=ff6000" width="1000" height="562" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>

body: ‘Full Stops’ is a musical arrangement made from the last notes of hundreds of the most famous classical songs downloaded on the Internet. Blending all classical eras from Baroque to Romantic passing by Classic, the work produces improbable encounters, including Mozart († 1791) and Tchaikovsky († 1893), Handel († 1759) and Rachmaninoff († 1943). The result is a new harmonious symphony, sometimes pompous, sometimes meditative, which begins and ends indefinitely, again and again.

title: Best Of Best Of Best Of
body: Best Of Best Of Best Of is a series of songs from various musicians and music bands. Each songs is a cumulative crescendo of the best of each artists turning into a cacophony. The work is shown within the form of an album listenable on iPod.

title: Emoticons

2 x 21 x 21 cm & 99 x 13 cm, 2011
Emoticons series, installation view, BYCR gallery, Milan, IT, 2013

body: For the series of EMOTICONS, Blumer has objectified the most widespread icon representing our emotions. This hyperbolic manner of showing emoticons intends to stimulate the audience to reflect on our daily-mediated relationship to each other, whether it is in a superficial or profound way. The emoticons are sort of emptied out symbols. Their primordial iconicity fades away because of our overuse of them. One could say that the more we use an emoticon the less it actually represents our emotional state. It’s, however, not always the case, the emoticons do still carry a profound power of self-reflectivity. Displayed within the traditional white cube, the Emoticons series doesn’t leave indifferent. They continuously inspire a reaction. Whether the viewers smile or not, they are caught in a ceaseless play on signs and signification since the emoticon exists at this strange edge between pure abstraction and representation.

title: Ellipsis
body: In a text, the ellipsis is signalled by 3 dots and brackets (…) which indicates when an author takes out some parts of an original text that is quoted in order to follow the logic of the argument. This absence is inevitably catching our attention and our mind eventually creates something to feed the gap. It is this lack in content of a text that the performance Ellipsis intends to question. The performance is made of 3 black dots covered with faux-fur hanged on a wall carefully and slowly shaved-off by the performers. As the ellipsis, the work is created through a subtraction of some of the original material. This antithetical action contrasts with traditional painting where commonly the material (paint) is added onto the canvas to generate new meanings. It also and mainly emphasis on how the “left un-told” becomes a condition for multiple. In this case, the ellipsis is not only the representation of a silent omission but also enhances a creative and fertile process, unfolding a variety of meaning, exploiting the void until it becomes productive.

title: Epi(deixis)

body: The word epideictic (epidittico in Italian) comes from the ancient Greek epideiktikosbased on deiknunai, which means ‘to show’. It is one of the three subdivisions of rhetoric as described in Aristotle’s book Rhetoric (367 – 322 BC). Epideixis is characterized by or designed to display rhetorical or oratorical skill. Epideixis is a demonstrative speech commonly used for opening events, anniversaries, births and funeral orations. Aristotle and many philosophers after him define Epideixis as a speech of style from which neither agonistic achievement nor polemic arouses. An epideictic oratorical demonstration does not provoke controversy but promotes values that are shared in the communities.

title: Balloons
body: The Balloon's Sculptures are simple metaphorical shapes expressing the confrontation between two languages, the agencies of the materials employed and the structure's layout.

title: Livestock
body: Livestock is a performance made at Goldsmiths College in 2009 that marks a transition between the 2 years work on the series Sweat Dreams and a new body of works opening up on different other mediums - performance, video, sculptures. It’s composed of an installation of 2 chairs, 1 salt painting representing a sheep, a hairdryer. The performer seated on the first chair makes a speech quoting Winston Churchill on notions of tradition, then licks half of the sheep painting, kneeling in front of it, dries the canvas out with the hairdryer and sits on the second chair.

title: Balloon#1
body: This performance explores the idea of exhaustion. The performer sited on a chair blows up a balloon and eventually disappear behind it. This monotonous task operated demands that the audience watches for a long time in order to know the end which is inevitable.

title: Green Pea (Balloon#2)
body: This performance explores the idea of exhaustion. The performer sited on a chair blows up a balloon and eventually disappear behind it. This monotonous task operated demands that the audience watches for a long time in order to know the end which is inevitable.

title: Sweat Dreams
body: The initial idea of this series of paintings was to reproduce the white traces left by human sweat on dark cloths when, for example, one makes sports or dance during hours. Painting, here, is conceptually and literally referring to a physical effort or labour; painting as work. With this technique the various visual references to art history amalgamate with improbable other references forming a mix of different languages uniformed aesthetically within one body of work. Like these non-perennial traces of salt on canvas, all the images have one thing in common: their potential disappearance.
